settings.page_title: Meet Valentine Pozzo di Borgo, Founder of Quintessence, Paris
settings.text: We couldnâ€™t wait for you to meet Valentine Pozzo di Borgo. The Parisian perfumer and dynamic entrepreneur inherited her love of perfume. Xavier Givaudan, her grandfather was a chemist from Lyon living in Switzerland, engraved his name in 1895 in the history of world perfumery by founding the homonymous group and by discovering many molecules, such as Lila 7. Her childhood memories are all associated with a perfume: the flasks in the office-laboratory, the long walks in the Swiss mountains and the Corsican maquis, the hours spent in perfumeries smelling new things â€¦ By composing olfactory universes, she perpetuates the family tradition while giving it a touch of femininity and modernity. We are so proud to showcase some of her creation and for you to discover more of her universe.

settings.text_block:
Can you tell us more about the history of Quintessence?Â 
Quintessence was born in 2008. But, I always knew I wanted to create my own company. First,Â I decided to dedicate myself to BtoB clients: creating olfactive identity for customers that had no access to the perfume world. This activity is called Quintessence Lab. I wanted to pursue a family tradition as my family has been in the perfume industry for almost 5 generations. Perfume was somehow in my blood.Â 
Then 2 years later, Quintessence Paris was launched as I wanted to open to a new clientele.

There is a history of perfume in your family?
Yes! I a descendant of the Givaudan family. They were chemists who created the first synthetic smells. They invented Lilac for example. The company that they created is still operational today. They sold it in the â€™60s butÂ GivaudanÂ still develops tastes and scents that delight consumers all over the world.

Do you remember your first memory of a scent?Â 
My first memory is associated with a place. The perfume of this moment is not describable as it is a mix of fragrance. It was vials in her grandfatherâ€™s laboratory.

You are both an artist and a designer, how do you approach your work?Â 

IÂ approach the everyday object in the same way as an art object, a painting or a sculpture.Â To design them, I like to have an artistic approach by experimenting with the material myselfÂ while developing its function.Â 

Do you remember how you first thought about these designs?Â 

Two years ago when I started embroidering trompe lâ€™oeil objects for my home, I really likedÂ their presence in the interior space. I was sensitive to both the decorative aspect and theÂ story they told me. It made me want to explore it on several furniture supports, like I do withÂ the table clothes right now.Â

What does embroidery mean to you?Â 

Embroidery involves patience and passion, itâ€™s precious. It is the transmission of a dailyÂ know-how, from family to family, from hand to hand. Thereâ€™s a slightly old-fashioned side to itÂ that I really enjoy! Itâ€™s like a piece of family memory I keep alive.Â 

You create objects for the table. What does â€œlâ€™Art de la Tableâ€ mean to you?Â 

It is the desire to create a beautiful table to receive and invite people we cherish, to share aÂ pleasant moment.Â

Do you think the confinement has changed the way people see their homes/tables?Â 

IÂ think people are very keen on objects that make them travel, escape from confinement.Â They want poetry, objects that inspire them, reassure them.Â 

What are your tips for the perfect table setting?Â 

A rather simple and not fancy table! Nice old plates, napkins, a vase, a bouquet, familyÂ heirlooms.Â

Where do you shop your interior pieces?Â 

Only on second-hand sites and by strolling around on flea markets. I donâ€™t buy a lot of newÂ items, which I often find to be of poor quality.

Any wishes for the rest of the year?Â 

Lots of beautiful things and objects to realize! ğŸ˜‰Â
